parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Size-sorting escape grids or systems reduced unwanted catches of most fish species assessed.
[Statement 2]: The effectiveness of size-sorting escape grids or systems varied by species, light conditions, and trawl type.
[Statement 3]: Topless (coverless) trawls reduced unwanted Atlantic cod catch and commercial fish discards compared to conventional trawls.
[Statement 4]: Mesh size-sorting funnels (sieve nets) on shrimp trawls reduced unwanted non-commercial or discarded fish catches.
[Statement 5]: Raising parts of bottom trawls off the seabed reduced unwanted sharks, elasmobranchs, and fish species compared to conventional trawls.
[Statement 6]: Changes to trawl wires, nets, codends, footropes, panels, or overall design reduced unwanted non-target and discarded fish catches.
[Statement 7]: Decreasing the circumference or diameter of a trawl's codend reduced discarded fish catch in some cases.
[Statement 8]: Modified mesh escape panels or windows reduced unwanted catches of certain species like whiting, haddock, and boarfish.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__In trawl fisheries, what are the most effective gear modifications for reducing unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from several studies shows mixed results for management interventions reducing fishing effort.
[Statement 2]: A before-and-after study in the Pacific Ocean found that involving fishers and stakeholders in co-management did not decrease overall fishing effort after five years.
[Statement 3]: Territorial fishing use rights showed no decrease in fishing effort over five years.
[Statement 4]: Overall catch limits, also known as quota caps, showed some success in reducing fishing effort.
[Statement 5]: A North Sea study found that when annual total allowable catch limits were changed, half of the otter trawl fleet had corresponding changes in fishing effort.
[Statement 6]: Long-term fishery closures showed positive results in reducing fishing effort.
[Statement 7]: A replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the North Sea found that long-term closure of a commercial fishery reduced overall fishing effort for lesser sandeel.
[Statement 8]: Temporary closures showed limited effectiveness in reducing fishing effort.
[Statement 9]: One North Sea study found that fixed temporary closures had little effect on fishing effort for cod.
[Statement 10]: Real-time area closures reduced the annual amount of cod caught.
[Statement 11]: The effect of limiting fishing activity by vessel size and engine power on fishing effort reduction was not specifically assessed.
[Statement 12]: Limiting fishing activity by vessel size and engine power was associated with a higher abundance of commercially targeted fish.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the evidence for management interventions successfully reducing fishing effort?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions are available to protect the reproductive success of commercially fished species?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence shows several fishery management actions can be used to protect the reproductive success of commercially fished species.
[Statement 2]: Setting minimum landing sizes allows fish to reach maturity and spawn before being caught.
[Statement 3]: Evidence shows mixed effectiveness for setting minimum landing sizes for fish.
[Statement 4]: One study reported only one of five swordfish fisheries showed increased recruitment after minimum sizes were set.
[Statement 5]: Another study found most landed fish were still immature despite established minimum sizes.
[Statement 6]: Protecting spawning fish from capture through seasonal closures and temporary fishery closures can provide protection during critical reproductive periods.
[Statement 7]: Evidence shows cod spent nearly a third of the cods' time in closed spawning areas during the implementation of closures.
[Statement 8]: Marine protected areas that prohibit harvesting of specific species like conch have shown increased abundance compared to fished areas.
[Statement 9]: Size-based management approaches specifying capture size ranges are available.
[Statement 10]: No studies have evaluated the effectiveness of size-based management approaches that specify capture size ranges.
[Statement 11]: Fishery management actions can work by preventing the capture of fish before the fish can reproduce.
[Statement 12]: Fishery management actions can work by protecting fish during spawning periods.
[Statement 13]: Fishery management actions can work by safeguarding critical reproductive habitats.

[Statement 1]: Prohibiting spearfishing in Mediterranean marine reserves provides significant conservation benefits.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting spearfishing in the Mediterranean increased the abundances of European seabass and gilthead seabream compared to fished areas after two to seven years.
[Statement 3]: Protected areas where spearfishing is prohibited resulted in larger fish sizes for European seabass compared to protected and unprotected fished areas.
[Statement 4]: Prohibiting spearfishing in specific zones of a Mediterranean marine reserve resulted in higher commercial and recreational fishery catches of targeted common dentex compared to zones that allowed spearfishing and areas outside the reserve after one to three years.
[Statement 5]: Marine protected areas in the Mediterranean prohibiting all fishing showed higher fish species richness compared to fished areas.
[Statement 6]: Marine protected areas in the Mediterranean prohibiting all fishing showed increased abundances and/or biomasses of fish.
[Statement 7]: Marine protected areas in the Mediterranean prohibiting all fishing resulted in larger fish overall after periods of protection ranging from one to 25 years.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the conservation benefits of prohibiting spearfishing in marine reserves in the Mediterranean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies examining the prohibition of different types of bottom fishing gear show varied effects on marine fish populations.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting all mobile and static fishing gears that catch bottom species showed mixed results.
[Statement 3]: One study found higher numbers of larger and older cod after 15 years of closure from all mobile and static fishing gears.
[Statement 4]: Another study found no effect on fish densities after 2-7 years of closure from all mobile and static fishing gears.
[Statement 5]: Fish densities varied between species and were influenced by depth and temperature.
[Statement 6]: Cod showed better growth in closed areas after 5-15 years compared to openly fished areas.
[Statement 7]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor demonstrated more consistent positive effects across 10 studies.
[Statement 8]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor resulted in higher total fish biomass after 15 years.
[Statement 9]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor resulted in increased adult red mullet biomass after 14 years.
[Statement 10]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor led to improved recruitment of young red mullet.
[Statement 11]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor led to larger sizes of adult red mullet.
[Statement 12]: The effects of prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor varied between individual fish groups and with habitat type.
[Statement 13]: One study showed increased catch rates after 3-6 years of prohibiting beach and seine nets.
[Statement 14]: Prohibiting shellfish dredging showed no effect on bottom-dwelling fish abundance or species richness after 10 years of closure.
[Statement 15]: Designated Marine Protected Areas that prohibit all towed fishing gear showed positive effects on invertebrate populations rather than fish.
[Statement 16]: Prohibiting all towed fishing gear in Marine Protected Areas resulted in greater invertebrate abundance and biomass compared to fished areas.
[Statement 17]: Prohibiting all towed fishing gear in Marine Protected Areas resulted in more scallops compared to fished areas.
[Statement 18]: Prohibiting all towed fishing gear in Marine Protected Areas resulted in higher proportions of older, larger scallops compared to fished areas.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the effects on marine fish populations of prohibiting different types of bottom fishing gear?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are some alternatives to setting catch quotas for controlling fishing mortality?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternatives to catch quotas for controlling fishing mortality have been documented.
[Statement 2]: Marine protected areas that prohibit fishing are a spatial management measure that can increase cod survival.
[Statement 3]: Move-on rules that trigger temporary closures are a spatial management measure that can reduce cod discards and fishing effort.
[Statement 4]: Prohibiting certain gear types is a gear-based control that can result in higher fish density and reduced unwanted cod catch.
[Statement 5]: Modifying fishing gear with escape frames is a gear-based control that can reduce the catch of undersized crabs.
[Statement 6]: Using alternative fishing methods is a gear-based control that can reduce unwanted fish catch and result in catching more mature specimens.
[Statement 7]: Limiting vessel size and power is an effort control that can lead to higher commercial fish abundance.
[Statement 8]: Permit limitations as an effort control for fishing lacked direct evidence of effectiveness.
[Statement 9]: Size-based management using minimum landing sizes has shown mixed results for reducing unwanted catches.
[Statement 10]: There was a lack of evidence for the effectiveness of maximum size limits as a size-based management tool.

[Statement 1]: The effects of prohibiting commercial fishing on fish abundance vary considerably across different ocean basins.
[Statement 2]: In the Atlantic Ocean/Gulf of Mexico, studies showed mixed results, with some commercially targeted species showing higher abundance after protection.
[Statement 3]: In the Atlantic Ocean/Gulf of Mexico, other commercially targeted species showed no change in abundance after protection.
[Statement 4]: The Mediterranean Sea demonstrated varied responses to fishing prohibitions, with some species groups showing higher abundance after five years.
[Statement 5]: In the Mediterranean Sea, species like white seabream showed no biomass increase after five years of protection.
[Statement 6]: The Indian Ocean showed mixed effects from fishing prohibitions, with some fish groups having higher abundance in protected areas.
[Statement 7]: The Indian Ocean showed mixed effects from fishing prohibitions, with larger overall fish size in protected areas.
[Statement 8]: The Tasman Sea region was notable for showing mostly decreased fish abundance or mixed results after fishing prohibition.
[Statement 9]: The South China Sea showed conflicting results, with decreased species richness following fishing prohibitions.
[Statement 10]: The South China Sea showed conflicting results, with increased overall fish density in the wider region.
[Statement 11]: The South Atlantic Ocean showed no significant differences in species composition or diversity after 40 years of protection.
[Statement 12]: Fish abundance responses to commercial fishing prohibition are highly variable between ocean basins.
[Statement 13]: There is no consistent global pattern of positive or negative effects on fish abundance from commercial fishing prohibition.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__How do the effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance vary across different ocean basins?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several management actions are available to protect fish reproductive capacity.
[Statement 2]: Key approaches to protect fish reproductive capacity include protecting spawning fish from capture through targeted measures.
[Statement 3]: Establishing temporary fishery closures during critical reproductive periods is a key approach to protect fish reproductive capacity.
[Statement 4]: Releasing gravid fish caught during spawning periods is a key approach to protect fish reproductive capacity.
[Statement 5]: Releasing male fish that guard nests during the breeding season represents another potential intervention.
[Statement 6]: Evidence for the practice of releasing male fish that guard nests during the breeding season is currently lacking.
[Statement 7]: Temporary closures have been implemented in various locations including the North Atlantic Ocean, Philippine Sea, and Mediterranean Sea.
[Statement 8]: Evidence suggests temporary closures can provide protection to adult fish during spawning periods when adult fish are most vulnerable.
[Statement 9]: Seasonally closed spawning areas have shown use by adult cod during spawning periods.
[Statement 10]: Seasonally closed spawning areas can provide effective protection during reproductive seasons.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What management actions are available to specifically protect the reproductive capacity of fish populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence for involving fishers and stakeholders in marine conservation management is limited.
[Statement 2]: A before-and-after study in the Indian Ocean found that involving fishers and stakeholders in co-management increased overall fish abundance nine years after implementation.
[Statement 3]: The Indian Ocean study also found that fish abundance varied between species groups.
[Statement 4]: A co-management study in the South China Sea reported decreased illegal fishing using destructive fishing gears after co-management was established.
[Statement 5]: A co-management study in the Pacific Ocean found no decrease in overall fishing effort and no increase in total fish catch rates after five years.
[Statement 6]: The Pacific Ocean study also found that catch rates decreased for half of the six species groups studied.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of engaging fishers in scientific data collection.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of including fishers in marine protected area management groups.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of engaging stakeholders when designing marine protected areas.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of involving stakeholders in harvest rights allocation.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of involving fishers in gear design.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of promoting knowledge exchange between fishers for marine fish populations.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the state of evidence for the effectiveness of involving fishers and other stakeholders in marine conservation management?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the most effective operational tactics for fishers to reduce unwanted catch without modifying the main structure of their nets or lines?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The most effective operational tactics for fishers to reduce unwanted catch without modifying main net or line structures include deploying gear at selected depths, deploying gear at specific times, using technology for real-time communication, and using different bait types.
[Statement 2]: Deploying fishing gear at selected depths can avoid unwanted species and was found to reduce unwanted catches of various fish and shark/ray species.
[Statement 3]: Deploying gear at specific times, such as during the day versus the night, reduced unwanted fish catches in prawn trawling.
[Statement 4]: Deploying gear at specific times avoided certain species like Harrison's dogfish in handlining operations in Australian waters.
[Statement 5]: Using technology to communicate near real-time catch information to fishers has achieved reductions in unwanted catch or discards.
[Statement 6]: Using different bait types reduced unwanted catches of undersized haddock, Atlantic cod, and other non-target fish.
[Statement 7]: No evidence was found for selectively avoiding fish based on temperature distribution as an effective operational tactic.

[Statement 1]: Introducing overall catch limits by fishery or fleet led to higher abundance or biomass of fish species like hakes, Atlantic herring and Atlantic halibut.
[Statement 2]: Introducing overall catch limits by fishery or fleet decreased fishing mortality compared to stocks without catch limits.
[Statement 3]: Prohibiting certain gear types was found to increase fish density when combined with other management measures.
[Statement 4]: Prohibiting certain gear types was found to reduce unwanted catch of species like cod when combined with other management measures.
[Statement 5]: Evidence on the effectiveness of establishing minimum landing sizes for commercially fished species is mixed.
[Statement 6]: Some studies show that establishing minimum landing sizes for commercially fished species reduced catches of the youngest fish.
[Statement 7]: Some studies found no reduction in unwanted catch after establishing minimum landing sizes for commercially fished species.
[Statement 8]: Deploying fishing gear at selected depths instead of traditional depths reduced unwanted catches of multiple fish and shark/ray species.
[Statement 9]: Reducing air exposure time of captured fish before release improved the physical condition and survival of the fish after release.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Besides closing areas to fishing, what alternative management strategies can reduce overall fishing mortality?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions are available for managing fishing activity within marine protected areas without imposing complete bans on all fishing.
[Statement 2]: Zonation systems allow different levels of fishing restrictions across different zones within the protected area.
[Statement 3]: Zones within a marine protected area can range from no-take zones to zones with partial fishing restrictions.
[Statement 4]: Fishing activity can be restricted through various unspecified limitations rather than complete prohibition.
[Statement 5]: Gear restrictions can be implemented, including limiting trap density.
[Statement 6]: Gear restrictions can include modifying trawl net configurations, such as mesh size, escape panels, twine types, and codend circumference.
[Statement 7]: Gear restrictions can include restricting vessel size or engine power.
[Statement 8]: Catch management tools include setting catch limits or quotas for targeted and non-targeted species.
[Statement 9]: Catch management tools include establishing minimum or maximum landing sizes for fish.
[Statement 10]: Catch management tools include creating move-on rules that trigger temporary area closures when catch thresholds are reached.
[Statement 11]: Temporal restrictions can be applied to fishing, such as establishing temporary fishery closures.
[Statement 12]: Temporal restrictions can include allowing periodic fishing only during specific time periods.
[Statement 13]: Temporal restrictions can involve implementing seasonal fishing restrictions.
[Statement 14]: Recreational fishing and harvesting can be specifically limited or prohibited while allowing commercial fishing to continue.
[Statement 15]: Management approaches for fishing have been shown to result in larger fish sizes compared to heavily fished areas.
[Statement 16]: Management approaches for fishing can result in greater abundance and biomass of fish populations compared to heavily fished areas.
[Statement 17]: Management approaches for fishing can result in different age and sex structures in fish populations compared to heavily fished areas.
[Statement 18]: Fishing management approaches can maintain some level of fishing activity.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions are available within a marine protected area to manage fishing activity without imposing a complete ban on all fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Turning diamond mesh orientation by 90° showed better size selection for cod, red mullet and round-bodied fish species compared to standard diamond mesh orientation.
[Statement 2]: Using square mesh codends instead of diamond mesh codends reduced unwanted fish catches of species including whiting, plaice, cod and haddock when combined with escape grids.
[Statement 3]: Different designs of size-sorting escape grid systems showed variable effectiveness for improving selectivity.
[Statement 4]: Some designs of size-sorting escape grid systems resulted in better size-selectivity for redfish, Greenland halibut and hake.
[Statement 5]: Combining mesh escape panels with size-sorting grids increased the size-selectivity of whiting compared to standard nets.
[Statement 6]: Modifying the configuration of mesh escape panels, such as position and mesh size, improved size-selectivity for haddock and whiting in some cases.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Which modifications to trawl nets appear most effective for improving size-selectivity?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Prohibiting line fishing was found to increase the abundance of over-exploited fish species.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting line fishing was found to increase the size of over-exploited fish species.
[Statement 3]: Prohibiting offshore line fishing and other boat-based fishing in marine protected areas resulted in higher abundances of four fish species compared to areas where boat-based line and spear fishing was permitted.
[Statement 4]: Prohibiting offshore line fishing and other boat-based fishing in marine protected areas resulted in larger fish sizes compared to areas where boat-based line and spear fishing was permitted.
[Statement 5]: Modifying longline configuration showed mixed effects on unwanted catch reduction.
[Statement 6]: Modifications such as using nylon instead of wire hook attachments on longlines reduced catches of unwanted sharks and rays in some cases.
[Statement 7]: Modifications such as increasing lead weight on mid-water longlines reduced catches of unwanted sharks and rays in some cases.
[Statement 8]: Longline modifications such as using nylon instead of wire hook attachments or increasing lead weight did not reduce catches of undersized haddock.
[Statement 9]: Using different bait types showed varying effectiveness in reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 10]: Using different bait types reduced unwanted catches of undersized haddock, Atlantic cod, and other non-target fish.
[Statement 11]: In some studies, using different bait types found no reduction in unwanted catches of pelagic stingray.
[Statement 12]: In some studies, using different bait types found no reduction in overall unwanted fish.
[Statement 13]: Prohibiting certain gear types was found to increase fish density.
[Statement 14]: Prohibiting certain gear types was found to reduce unwanted catch.
[Statement 15]: Higher fish density was found in areas where all but one gear type was prohibited.
[Statement 16]: Prohibiting non-selective gear types reduced unwanted cod catch.
[Statement 17]: Comprehensive fishing prohibitions in marine protected areas showed mixed results on fish populations.
[Statement 18]: Some marine protected areas with comprehensive fishing prohibitions showed similar or lower fish abundance compared to unprotected areas.
[Statement 19]: One study found increased cod survival after prohibiting almost all fishing.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the documented effects of different restrictions on line fishing, such as prohibitions or gear modifications, on fish populations and unwanted catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Multiple gear modifications are available for prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries to reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 2]: Size-sorting escape grids (rigid or flexible) fitted to prawn/shrimp trawl nets are the most extensively studied modification for reducing unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 3]: Size-sorting escape grids reduce unwanted fish catches by allowing the escape of non-commercial species and discarded commercial species.
[Statement 4]: Sieve nets, which are size-sorting mesh funnels fitted to prawn/shrimp trawl nets, reduce catches of unwanted fish compared to standard trawls.
[Statement 5]: Large, supported escape openings such as Fisheyes, Bigeyes and radial escape sections can reduce overall catches of unwanted fish.
[Statement 6]: Large, supported escape openings such as Fisheyes, Bigeyes and radial escape sections can reduce catches of undersized individuals.
[Statement 7]: Mesh escape panels or windows combined with square mesh codends instead of diamond mesh can reduce the number of discarded finfish.
[Statement 8]: The combination of size-sorting escape grids with large, supported escape openings is effective in reducing unwanted fish catches.
[Statement 9]: The combination of size-sorting escape grids with large, supported escape openings is effective in reducing unwanted shark and ray catches.
[Statement 10]: Moving devices, also known as stimulator devices, can increase the escape of certain fish species by triggering their escape responses.
[Statement 11]: Gear modifications in prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries work by providing escape routes for fish while retaining the target prawn and shrimp catch.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__In prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries, what gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several modifications to static fishing gear can reduce unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 2]: For gillnets, modifications including reduced net height, increased tension, increased twine diameter, and changes to mesh size and orientation have shown effectiveness in reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 3]: The aforementioned gillnet modifications have been shown to reduce the unwanted catch of cod.
[Statement 4]: The gillnet modifications have been effective in reducing discarded fish of commercial and non-commercial species.
[Statement 5]: The gillnet modifications mentioned did not typically reduce unwanted shark catches in one study.
[Statement 6]: For traps and pots, increasing mesh size has been shown to reduce the proportion of unwanted undersized mud crabs caught.
[Statement 7]: Fitting traps and pots with escape frames or grids has been shown to reduce the proportion of unwanted undersized mud crabs caught.
[Statement 8]: Combining escape frames with larger mesh on traps and pots has been shown to reduce the proportion of unwanted undersized mud crabs caught.
[Statement 9]: Trap design modifications showed varying results for unwanted catch depending on the specific design and location.
[Statement 10]: Some modified trap designs caught legal-size target species while other trap designs caught none.
[Statement 11]: Using different bait types showed mixed results for reducing unwanted fish catches.
[Statement 12]: Some studies found that using different bait types reduced unwanted catches of undersized haddock, Atlantic cod, and other non-target fish.
[Statement 13]: Other studies found no difference in unwanted catches of pelagic stingray, sharks, and rays when using different bait types.
[Statement 14]: Some studies found no difference in overall unwanted fish catch when using different bait types.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the most effective modifications for static fishing gear, like gillnets and traps, to reduce unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Multiple gear modifications are available to reduce unwanted fish catch in commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries.
[Statement 2]: Size-sorting escape grids, which can be rigid or flexible, have been extensively studied.
[Statement 3]: Research shows size-sorting escape grids can reduce unwanted fish catches of non-commercial species and discarded commercial species or sizes by allowing fish to escape.
[Statement 4]: Size-sorting escape grids can be used alone or in combination with large, supported escape openings.
[Statement 5]: Mesh escape panels or windows used together with size-sorting grids have proven effective in reducing the unwanted catch of fish, sharks and stingrays when compared to standard nets.
[Statement 6]: Size-sorting mesh funnels, also known as sieve nets, have shown success in reducing catches of unwanted non-commercial or discarded fish in North Sea studies.
[Statement 7]: Moving devices designed to stimulate a fish escape response have been tested.
[Statement 8]: Tested moving devices have shown an increased escape of some species, such as young red seabream.
[Statement 9]: The combination of mesh escape panels or windows with soft, rigid or semi-rigid grids can reduce the total weight of small unwanted catch.
[Statement 10]: The combination of mesh escape panels or windows with soft, rigid or semi-rigid grids can decrease unwanted large sponge catches.
[Statement 11]: Combining mesh escape panels or windows with grids may also reduce the targeted prawn catch.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish in commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the evidence for gear modifications improving the size-selectivity of commercial fishing gear?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence shows that various gear modifications significantly improve the size-selectivity of commercial fishing gear.
[Statement 2]: Studies demonstrate that modifications to trawl gear design improve size-selectivity for unwanted fish species and sizes.
[Statement 3]: Square mesh escape panels and windows enhance size selection.
[Statement 4]: Studies have shown improved selectivity when square mesh escape panels and windows are fitted to trawl nets.
[Statement 5]: Fitting square mesh escape panels and windows to trawl nets resulted in better selection for Atlantic cod and haddock.
[Statement 6]: The effects of square mesh escape panels and windows on selectivity varied with panel position and design.
[Statement 7]: Rotating diamond mesh orientation by 90° in trawl codends improved size selection for cod, red mullet and round-bodied fish species.
[Statement 8]: The combination of square mesh escape panels with size-sorting grids increased size-selectivity for whiting.
[Statement 9]: Size-sorting escape grids, when fitted to fish trawl nets, improved size-selection of haddock in some cases.
[Statement 10]: Grids on prawn/shrimp trawls reduced unwanted undersized fish catches.
[Statement 11]: Using square mesh codends combined with escape grids resulted in better size selection compared to standard configurations.

[Statement 1]: Documented ecological outcomes of managing small-scale traditional fisheries show mixed results.
[Statement 2]: A study in the Adriatic Sea found that a marine protected area allowing only artisanal fishing for three years had higher overall commercial catch rates for five of seven species.
[Statement 3]: The catch rates in the Adriatic Sea's marine protected area were compared to unprotected areas that were openly fished.
[Statement 4]: A study of prohibiting customary fishing in Papua New Guinea showed limited ecological benefits.
[Statement 5]: After eight years of closure from customary fishing in Papua New Guinea, only one of seven fish species showed higher abundance.
[Statement 6]: Six of seven fish species in the Papua New Guinea study showed a lower flight response distance after the closure.
[Statement 7]: The lower flight response distance of the fish could potentially make the fish more vulnerable to spear gun capture.
[Statement 8]: Community-based fisheries management in New Zealand showed positive outcomes for scallop populations.
[Statement 9]: Customary fisheries areas in New Zealand had more New Zealand scallops compared to fully protected areas or areas allowing recreational harvest.
[Statement 10]: Scallops in New Zealand's customary fisheries areas tended to be smaller.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the documented ecological outcomes of managing small-scale traditional fisheries, either through prohibition or by making them the only permitted fishing type?
